unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Math Program: Appropriate Test Type
question_text: Suppose a high school principal wishes to determine if students in her after-school math program perform better than those not in the program. The principal randomly selected $115\text{ students}$ for an after-school study session that runs $3\text{ days per week}$ for $1\text{ hour}$ each day, focusing solely on math. The grade distribution of these students’ math grades is compared to the historical grade distribution of students’ math grades at this high school. The data is below: A B C D F After-School Program (Counts) 28 38 36 9 4 Historical Grade Distribution (%) 18% 32% 25% 20% 5% When performing a chi-squared test for goodness of fit, suppose strong evidence exists that students in the program have math grades different than everybody else does. What kind of test would one use to prove the claim that the course actually improves math grades?
